content:
https://www.codingame.com/replay/481657739
The dropped tiles on the last round suddenly change colour for a brief moment.

Though its approved but i found a bug fix it.
The game has crashed. Please contact the author and enclose the following error:

java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: Index 1 out of bounds for length 1
	at com.codingame.game.engine.GameState.validate(GameState.java:59)
	at com.codingame.game.Referee.gameTurn(Referee.java:69)
	at com.codingame.gameengine.core.GameManager.start(GameManager.java:122)
	at com.codingame.gameengine.core.RefereeMain.start(RefereeMain.java:67)
	at com.codingame.gameengine.core.RefereeMain.main(RefereeMain.java:50)
its happening when user is not giving space between output like giving "00" instead of "0 0"

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Original et bien réalisé.
Un certain challenge pour performer.
Because the validators are standard test cases, there are known records for each of them or for the sum of them. Wouldn't it be worth to add these numbers in the statement ?
Cool, looking forward to this one!

I was a bit confused by this: "First 15 lines: rows of the board, top (row 14) to bottom (row0). " because it forced me to reverse the rows of my grid. But it's not a big deal. (I'm also a fan of (row, column) instead of (x, y) but it's easy to adapt :).)

Apart from that, it seems to be working and I'm glad we'll have this puzzle on CodinGame, it's a must have.

That's actually on this game that I learned SP-MCTS (and had to learn MCTS)! I'll give it a shot when I'll have some time.

Thanks for the contribution!
You think make a contest ?

I like the contribution and intend to approve it.
I'd just like to see different testcases: you have 20 validators and then the same again with different colors. For my program they are still the same. I think just random would do better here.
The first few testcases are a bit boring and give most of the points. But as testcases I guess they are fine. They aren't validators after all.

Y starting at the bottom is a bit unconventional for CodinGame standards but no big deal ;)
"Indices must start at 0, not 1. The origin is always the top left pixel/tile."
https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/contribute---help/coding-games#guidelines

OK - I updated the puzzle.
Important changes:
- now you can make your action turn-by-turn (color -1 for empty tile)
- no more warnings - selecting illegal action causes hard error.
Pretty cool game !
It's very cool !

Thank you for your approval so far - but I agree that the CG community will gain if I simplify the problem and allow solutions not requiring writing the engine.

I should make an update in the next few days.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice simple problem: various number of possible complex solutions.
Why not have created an infinite loop to make the game easier for beginners?

Oups
An error occurred (#510): "An error has occurred during compilation/execution.".
Is this error is with me only?

Nice game. +1

Would it be possible to see in the intro how the column moves ? to illustrate :

"Then, for every empty column, all columns that are on the right are moved maximally to the left, so that the row 0 has no gaps. "

Havent tried much yet, but great idea for a game here :)

I think the player should either "lose" or at least stop the sequence of moves, when doing an illegal move, instead of just a warning. And 20sec, even for 1 turn only, seems to much? Thats 16 minutes just for the testcases, if you use all 20sec for 50 cases.

Any way, take my upvote :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I find it interesting and really well made. The visualization is great and looks like an actual game I played a few years back.

I agree.

Illegal move => instant lose, its a lot easier to debug

Ouh I was not aware that intro stops after some frames.
Nide idea I will try to find something better, thanks.

When I'm updating, from time to time the package I send causes this error. No idea why - the build is nearly the same.

Thanks for pointing this out.

It should be working again.

Mostly - to be consistent with the standard benchmark scenarios in publications.
I was thinking about that, but this creates this weird choice of time-spending. Either there will be insignificant time per turn to just make non-optimal strategies 'work'. 
Or this time will be significant and you have to tune your algorithm to handle planning and searching.
I recommend switching to WIP, lest the contribution be approved as it is.

Actually I wanted to make the same testcases not repeated 2 times but at least 10 but cannot make so many validators.
Tascases are standard research benchmark, and allow you to compare with other positions in literature.

About Y at the bottom... it seems natural as you converge to 0,0 when all the tiles are consistently disappearing.

No, I don't think so.
There will be exercise list for my course based on this puzzle, with some "try this and that algorithm, report how they behave, bonus for obtaining score >= something".
I may publish it, but that's probably all ;-).

I know - but I really think converging to 0, 0 is natural here, so I'm not about to change it until really forced to ;p.

Good point with (x,y) to (row,column), silly cat I didn't think of this. I've changed it of course - It's much more clear that way - and I have to remember the case for the future.

And I'm really glad you like it :-).

You have some 'bestscore' in the human-playing link, I'm pretty sure someone mentioned somewhere that they were obtained programmatically...

On the other hand, it is actually hard to say, as I know some unpublished papers that already beat what is currently 'best score'.

So just search the literature at the time of writing.
thanks for reporting, I will catch this one
Yeah, I've noticed this before but given I'm so happy it already worked after multiple iterations of much weirder stuff happening I didn't found a fix for this one.
OK, fixed. I should always catch general exception not pretend to be smart what java may throw at me  ^^'
A course ? It's genially !

I'm teaching "Artificial Intelligence for Games" at my university.
There is some slight chance that this year I will make some materials public and promote them on CG, but that depends on some circumstances ^^'.
I would read them with pleasure! :grinning:

I got your idea for using benchmark tests.

But let's talk about how users will play this game:
some will write a deterministic solution, giving the exact same score agnostic to the coloring. Others will solve the testcases offline with more than the 20s computation time. Having more different testcases helps to reduce the random factor here.
I'm not arguing against the benchmark tests, only against the repetition of them.

Ehhh, I got your point, but imo in this case ~40 testcases are better than 20, as most of the solutions  (the 'good ones') will be nondeterministic, this somewhat mitigates the factor of going well in this submission.

But 40 distinct testcases are better than 2 * 20 :P
So I vote for keeping the 20 benchmark tests and generating 20 random ones.

No idea how they will behave, though.
CG does not show your score for individual tests, only global, so that way your score will be incomparable to any existing benchmarks. 
Now you just divide by 2 to get an average score on the standard testset.

You can adjust the benchmark testcases to make them visible in the IDE too (the testXX.json files):

"isTest": "true",
"isValidator": "true"

This will make the test playable in the IDE and executed on submit.
Just don't add the "introduction tests" to the submit score please.

But for the leaderboard you are right: it's not comparable.
Right - I wanted to do this but forgot, thx.
I checked that now again its working ,You fixed that?
yeah, recompile and reupload...
OK, there is some column reduction in the replay...

I allowed illegal moves to not force people to implement a full game mechanic right away. Now you can work with even random (0-14, 0-14, although the score would be awful - and improve your program gradually,

The timelimits were consulted with CG officials, and actually they are far below the allowed upperbound. Publications usually show results  for even few times larger timelimits, so I had to choose something that will be reasonable to compare.
Fair point for the illegal moves, and for the timelimit as well. Just seems there is less "room" for competing in optimisation with that much time. But I hear (read) you :)
